Uses: Ocular drug preservative
MOA: Increases absorption of drug by disrupting epithelium
Toxicities: Hypersensitivity reactions, epithelial damage

Uses: Adrenergic agonist: vasoconstrictor/decongestant(a1)
MOA: Acts on a and B1 receptors
Toxicities: Ischemia

Uses: Adrenergic agonist: weak mydriatic (a1), antiglaucoma (a1,a2,b2), vasoconstrictor/decongestant(a1), bronchodilator, anti-allergic in anaphylaxis
MOA: Acts on a receptors, B receptors may play a role
Toxicities: Hypertension, agitiation, tachycardia, dysrhythmia

Uses: Adrenergic agonist: mydriatic (a1), vasoconstrictor/decongestant(a1), bronchodilator, anti-allergic in anaphylaxis, treat sympathetic denervation ptosis, break posterior synechiae (10%)
MOA: Acts on a1 receptors
Toxicities: Burning and local irritation, can precipitate a narrow angle glaucoma attack, libration of pigment, keratitis, conjunctival hypoxia

Uses: Adrenergic agonist: antiglaucoma (a1 and more selective for a2)
MOA: Acts on a2 post-synaptic receptors, inhibit adenylate cyclase, decrease cAMP, decrease aqueous production, increase uveoscleral outflow, diagnose Horner's
Toxicities: Allergic reactions, mydriasis, lid retraction, conjuctival blankching, dry mouth, fatigue, lethargy, headache, head cold symptoms

Uses: Adrenergic agonist: antiglaucoma (a2)
MOA: Acts on a2 post-synaptic receptors, inhibit adenylate cyclase, decrease cAMP, decrease aqueous production, increase uveoscleral outflow, maybe neuroprotective
Toxicities: Hyperemia, stinging, burning, blurred vision, FBS, dry mouth, headache, fatigue, lethargy, drowsiness

Uses: Adrenergic agonist: a1 agonist, decongestant, relieve minor irritation
MOA: Acts on a1 receptors to constrict blood vessels
Toxicities: Rebound hyperemia

Uses: Adrenergic agonist: mydriasis, diagnosis of post-ganglionic SNS denervation (Horner's)
MOA: Stimulates release of NE, blocks reuptake and some inhibition of MAO
Toxicities: Seizures, hyperemia, tachycardia, hallucinations, death

Uses: Adrenergic agonist: mydriasis, vasoconstriction, anestheisa, Horner's diagnosis
MOA: Indirectly blocks NE reuptake
Toxicities: Mydriasis, headache, increase in BP, elevated body temperature, increase/decrease heart rate

Uses: Adrenergic antagonist: (a-blocker) reverse phenylephrine mydriasis
MOA: Blocks alpha receptors, preventing agonist binding
Toxicities: Conjunctival hyperemia, corneal irritation, corneal edema, ptosis, lid edema, erythema

Uses: Non-selective beta blocker: decrease aqueous production, open angle glaucoma treatment, chronic treatment of narrow angle glaucoma, angle closure
MOA: Blocks beta receptors, decrease aqueous production
Toxicities: Irritation and lacrimation, dry eye, corneal hypoesthesia, blurred vision, uveitis, myasthenic symptoms

Uses: Beta receptor partial agonist
MOA: Partially activates beta receptors, decreases aqueous production from normal levels
Toxicities: Burning and lacrimation, dry eye, corneal hypoesthesia, blurred vision, uveitis, myasthenic symptoms

Uses: Cholinergic agent: miosis (short-lived)
MOA: Acts on nicotinic and muscarinic receptors
Toxicities: None

Uses: Cholinergic agent: miosis, prevent increased IOP in cataract extractions
MOA: Acts on nicotinic and muscarinic receptors, not susceptible to AchE
Toxicities: More intense miosis, hyperemia, CB contraction, lacrimation, pupillary block with 2ary angle closure glaucoma, retinal detachment

Uses: Cholinergic agent: miosis, glaucoma treatment (POAG), treat acute angle closure attack
MOA: Acts on nicotinic and muscarinic receptors, not susceptible to AchE, binds to pigment, increases accommodation, increases aqueous outflow
Toxicities: Accommodative spasm, follicular conjuctivitis, pupillary block with 2ary angle closure glaucoma, retinal detachment

Uses: Indirect parasympathomimetic: treat glaucoma and accommodative esotropia
MOA: Inhibits AchE, long-acting and irreversible
Toxicities: More intense accommodative spasm, follicular conjuctivitis, pupillary block with 2ary angle closure glaucoma, retinal detachment

Uses: Ecothiophate/Phospholine antidote
MOA: Reactivates AchE
Toxicities: None - system goes back to normal

Uses: Antimuscarinic: cycloplegia, mydriasis, decrease ciliary spasm in inflammation, treat amblyopia
MOA: Blocks muscarinic receptors, longest lasting and most potent
Toxicities: (0.5mg) bradycardia, dry mouth, anhydrosis (1) tachycardia (2) palpitations, mydriasis (5) slurred speech, agitated, fever (10) flushed, rapid weak pulse, ataxia, delirium, convulsion, coma, death

Uses: Antimuscarinic: cycloplegia (drug of choice), mydriasis, decrease ciliary spasm in inflammation
MOA: Blocks muscarinic receptors, short acting
Toxicities: Irritation and lacrimation, conjuctival hyperemia, allergic blepharoconjuctivitis, elevated IOP, incoherent speech, restlessness, hallucinations, ataxia

Uses: Antimuscarinic: cycloplegia, mydriasis (drug of choice)
MOA: Blocks muscarinic receptors, short acting cycloplegic, absorbed fastest
Toxicities: dryness of mouth, nose, throat, bronchi; photophobia, rapid and irregular pulse

Uses: Antimuscarinic: treat inflammatory eye disease exclusively
MOA: Blocks muscarinic receptors, longer acting to prevent accommodative spasm
Toxicities: flushing, dry skin, allergy

Uses: Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitor: Systemically administered; treat glaucoma
MOA: Travels through the blood to the eye to inhibit carbonic anhydrase from undergoing reactions to produce aqueous humor
Toxicities: Paresthesia, headaches, drowsiness, fatigue, dizziness, muscle weakness, malaise, diuresis, renal stones and colic, myopia

Uses: Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitor: Topically administered; treat glaucoma
MOA: Inhibits carbonic anhydrase from undergoing reactions to produce aqueous humor
Toxicities: Irritation/keratitis, buring, blurred vision, FBS, corneal edema or decomposition esp with previus intraocular surgery, headache, bitter taste

Uses: Prostaglandin analog: PGF2alpha analog; treat glaucoma
MOA: Binds to receptor FP, remodels the ECM to reduce the collagen levels in the ciliary muscle and sclera by increasing production of matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) to increase uveoscleral outflow
Toxicities: Punctate keratopathy, increase in iris pigmentation, increase eyelash growth and periocular pigmentation, cystoid macular edema, corneal pseudodendrites

Uses: Osmotic Agent: treat glaucoma
MOA: Rapidly increases plasma osmolarity, extracting fluid from tissues
Toxicities: Decreased CSF, headache, dry mouth and thirst, nausea, vomiting, hyperosmotic coma and possible death, congestive heart failure, pulmonary edema, muscle cramps and weakness

Uses: Topical Ocular Anesthetic
MOA: Reversibly block Na+ channels, preventing Na+ influx and nerve depolarization. Blocks from inside the channel in an ionized state
Toxicities: mild epithelial staining and edema with cytotoxic LA and/or preservatives, conjunctival hyperemia, decre.TBUT, decr. blink rate, decr. tear secretion, reduced epithelial regeneration, block mitosis
